name: Novel cystic fibrosis option safe, but no sign of efficacy
introduction: Translate Bio stock fell by a quarter in pre-market trading on Thursday, after interim data from a small trial testing mRNA candidate MRT5005 in cystic fibrosis (CF) failed to impress.
content:
Translate Bio (Nasdaq: TBIO) stock fell by a quarter in pre-market trading on Thursday, after interim data from a small trial testing mRNA candidate MRT5005 in cystic fibrosis (CF) failed to impress.

MRT5005 is the first clinical-stage prospect of its type to address the underlying cause of CF through a unique mechanism of action.

Importantly, the Phase I/II study showed that repeat dosing of MRT5005 was generally safe and well tolerated, with no serious adverse events.

However, investors will be disappointed to see that there was no observed pattern of increased lung function as of yet.

Translate said the data supported advancement of mRNA therapeutics for pulmonary diseases, and that it would keep working to “optimize future clinical development” of both MRT5005 and “a next-generation CF candidate.”

The firm said that its next-generation CF discovery program has generated positive pre-clinical data and that investigational new drug (IND)-enabling studies would kick off in the second half of 2021.

Focus on Sanofi collab

While Translate Bio’s work in pulmonary diseases has potential, analysts are also looking to the US biotech’s collaboration and license agreement with French pharma major Sanofi (Euronext: SAN) as a source of future value.

Building on an existing 2018 collaboration, the firms agreed in mid-2020 to work together on the development of mRNA vaccines across all infectious disease areas.

As a consequence, Translate Bio received $425 million upfront, and became eligible for $1.9 billion in potential milestone payments, plus royalties on sales.

Commenting on the latest trial data, chief executive Ronald Renaud said it was “the first time messenger RNA encoding CFTR has been administered to patients with cystic fibrosis through inhaled repeat doses.”

Chief medical officer Ann Barbier said: “Based on the first and second interim analyses, we believe we have achieved a safety profile that supports repeat dosing of inhaled mRNA and further advancement of the pulmonary platform for chronic dosing.”
meta_keywords: cystic, fibrosis, Translate, data, mRNA, candidate, interim, trial, safe, efficacy, sign, option, Thursday, trading, pre-market, quarter, fell, stock, smal
